instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PM_S0_PGOOD: What is PM_S0_PGOOD?  PM_S0_PGOOD is created when CPUVR_PGOOD and ALL_SYS_PWRGD are present and branches off to become PM_PCH_PWROK. PM_S0_PGOOD and SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD are necessary to create SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MBP 15" 2012 - Dead
threads.message:
not liquid damaged, so gonna be a hard one :/ I don't know the history of this board.

magsafe goes green then orange. so charging is working. but won't power up. I can see fan tries to spin but couldnt.

PCH get hot, I can't keep on my finger on it for long.
so system is trying to get into fully S0 and already partially is in a S0 state,

Dead PCH?


<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.393v
<SIGNAL>PPCHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> = 16.45v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> IS 12.55v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> = 5v
PM_SLP_S3_ = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_PCH</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>MEMVTT_EN</SIGNAL> = 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 5v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0_REG</SIGNAL> = 1.78v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> = 0.032v

CPU VCORE = 0
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PM_S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PVCCSA_PGOOD</SIGNAL> = 00.05v
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>= 0.016v


<TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR>
pin1 = 0.018v
pin3 = 0.015v
pin4 = 0.16v
pin5 = 1.071v
pin6 = 3.294v
pin7 = 1.5v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MBP 15" 2012 - Dead
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> should obviously be 1.05 volts. Resistance to ground on that rail?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MBP 15" 2012 - Dead
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 36992"]<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> should obviously be 1.05 volts. Resistance to ground on that rail?[/QUOTE]

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> = with 9.5 ohms to ground

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MBP 15" 2012 - Dead
threads.message: So you have a short on <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>. Inject voltage to see what's getting hot. Because the PCH is getting hot, start with around 0.5 volts to see if it's the only thing getting warm.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MBP 15" 2012 - Dead
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 36995"]So you have a short on <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>. Inject voltage to see what's getting hot. Because the PCH is getting hot, start with around 0.5 volts to see if it's the only thing getting warm. [/QUOTE]

just tried, nothing get warm with that small voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MBP 15" 2012 - Dead
threads.message:
10ohms looks like normal value for PCH core.
Check if <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> gets correct power and enable signal.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> requires its PGOOD to rise up...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MBP 15" 2012 - Dead
threads.message: My known good I have in for backlight has about 100 ohms to ground on 1v05, so idk if it's just a one off, but I could be wrong about short. When you inject voltage does the amperage jump up or stay at zero?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MBP 15" 2012 - Dead
threads.message: it does have short, amperage goes up and I had to rise the voltage to least 2.1v just so I can get 1v readings on the multimeter.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MBP 15" 2012 - Dead
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MBP 15" 2012 - Dead
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MBP 15" 2012 - Dead
threads.message: when I inject 1v, i get 0.5v reading on the board. inject 2.1v, I get 1v on the board. perfectly fine when you have short like that as long the reading on the multimeter is not 2.1v then you would kill everything on the PP1v05 rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MBP 15" 2012 - Dead
threads.message:
NEVER inject a voltage higher than there is supposed to be. I have no idea what power supply you are using that if you set 1V you get 0.5V because of the short. That means the PSU is current limiting, the wiring is dropping voltage or the PSU is just crap.

This does sound like a dead PCH to start with.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MBP 15" 2012 - Dead
threads.message:
yes current limiting. its a switch mode PSU. not very good for the job. I have not killed anything. I does this on most repair as long the multimeter readings for the voltage is not higher than there is supposed to..

I dont have rework station yet, another board to store in the basement.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MBP 15" 2012 - Dead
threads.message:
I want to get a BGA rework station, possibly a Jovy RE-8500, I have like 10 mixers of PC and Mac boards that I require a BGA rework station. if I repair these boards then the BGA rework station will paid for it self once these boards are fixed.

when you want to buy a preball BGA chip from eBay or Aliexpress, how do you search the chip you want?

for example

A PCH for MacBook Pro 15" 2012, it has Intel. E2088369 Platform Controller.

do you search E2088369 or SLJ8C? Are all SLJ8C the same, PC, Macs compatible?

[IMG type="full" width="200px"]https://i.imgur.com/SXGqiQJ.png[/IMG]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MBP 15" 2012 - Dead
threads.message:
SLJ8C should get you the chip you need. ME region will need fixing after replacing but board should at least turn on.

Also don't think you can just replace BGAs when getting a rework station. It requires some practice and patience and "feel" to get things right. Have some crap board to practice on first!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MBP 15" 2012 - Dead
threads.message: Jovy RE-8500, used for £850. is this a good deal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MBP 15" 2012 - Dead
threads.message: Depends on condition. I think it's a lot of money....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MBP 15" 2012 - Dead
threads.message:
Do you have any recommendations? i really want to learn. especially should paid for itself after many repairs.

do you have a Zhuomao like the one Louis Rossmann uses?

i found a Quick BGA station but i doubt you can find any spare parts when something break also Quick has discontinued this model.

[URL="https://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/Quick-I760B-Infrared-BGA-Rework-Station/112957697326?hash=item1a4ccdad2e:g:l60AAOSwBIRa3kyM"]https://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/Quick-I76...0AAOSwBIRa3kyM[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MBP 15" 2012 - Dead
threads.message:
I recommend not to deal with large BGAs. GPUs that are actually real and new are unobtanium so that only leaves the rare PCH replacement. I know you don't wanted to get this answer but this is why these rework stations are on Ebay 2nd hand. 

Unless you find a source for real new GPUs you will not use a rework station enough to justify the $1K. I think I replaced 1 PCH so far this year.....
